titlestmt.titleproper: Ford Foundation records, Rights and Social Justice Program, AIDS Initiative
A Guide to Ford Foundation records, Rights and Social Justice Program, AIDS Initiative FA1418

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on 2020-10-21 06:27:44 -0400.

did.unittitle: Ford Foundation records, Rights and Social Justice Program, AIDS Initiative

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The collection is arranged into one series: National-Community AIDS Partnership Files

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: Open for research with select materials restricted as noted. Brittle or damaged items are available at the discretion of RAC.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: This material was transferred to RAC in 2018 by the Ford Foundation and ingested by RAC as Accession 2018:018.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The collection contains reports, correspondence, press clippings, and staff subject files related to the National-Community AIDS Partnership and the National AIDS Network.
The collection also includes materials regarding philanthropic responses to the AIDS crisis more broadly.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: In June 1987, the Ford Foundation appointed a panel of experts to examine needs posed by the AIDS epidemic. The panel determined that private philanthropy could step in to provide social services, practical support to individuals with AIDS and their families, and design community education programs.

The Ford Foundation Board of Trustees established a National-Community AIDS Partnership (NCAP) to support community-based efforts to provide preventive education and social services for people with AIDS.

The Ford Foundation initially contributed $2 million to the Partnership, but ultimately contributed $15 million to strengthen philanthropic support for AIDS-related needs between 1988 and 1998. The Partnership, composed of private foundations and corporate donors, was housed at the National AIDS Network (NAN) in Washington, DC.

In 1988, the National-Community AIDS Partnership targeted locations included: Atlanta, Connecticut, Greater Cleveland, Minnesota, Northern California, New York/New Jersey, Southern California and Southwest Border States, and Washington, DC.
